Fig 9 MOF derived non-noble metal catalysts to control the distribution of furfural selective hydrogenation products Zhuo-Fei Li a Yan Shen a Wen-Gang Cui a Qiang Zhang a Tong-Liang Hu a b ⁎ a School of Materials Science and Engineering, National Institute for Advanced Materials, Nankai University, Tianjin 300350, China School of Materials Science and Engineering National Institute for Advanced Materials Nankai University Tianjin 300350 China aSchool of Materials Science and Engineering, National Institute for Advanced Materials, Nankai University, Tianjin 300350, China b State Key Laboratory of Coordination Chemistry, Nanjing University, Nanjing 210023, China State Key Laboratory of Coordination Chemistry Nanjing University Nanjing 210023 China bState Key Laboratory of Coordination Chemistry, Nanjing University, Nanjing 210023, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Furfural, as one of the most important and attractive platform molecules, could produce high-value chemicals through selective hydrogenation, which had attracted wide attention in recent years. Hereon, a ZnCo bimetal ZIF (ZnCo-ZIF-US) was quickly and efficiently prepared by an ultrasonic-assisted method, and a series of nitrogen-doped carbon-coated bimetallic composites (ZnCo-US@NC-T, T refers to the calcination temperature) were prepared by a one-step calcination technique from ZnCo-ZIF-US and their structures were characterized in detail by PXRD, SEM, TEM, and XPS etc. The obtained ZnCo-US@NC-700 showed higher catalytic performance in the selective hydrogenation of furfural to furfuryl alcohol than the derivatives of ZnCo bimetal ZIF prepared without ultrasonic-assisted. Surprisingly, the results showed the presence or absence of Zn in the catalysts could regulate the hydrogenation products of furfural to produce furfuryl alcohol or tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol. In addition, the catalyst could be recycled with almost no significant change in catalytic performance and its microstructure was still well maintained. This work provides an ingenious strategy for the selective regulation of biomass products. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Biomass MOF derived catalyst Selective hydrogenation Furfural Introduction As a galore sustainable resource, biomass can be converted into chemicals or liquid fuels to replace fossil resources under the background of rapid consumption of fossil fuels and air pollution, which has caught everyone's attention [1-9]. Furfural (FFL), mainly obtained through the hydrolysis of hemicellulose, is one of the representative biomass-derived molecular compounds, and is also the link between biomass resources and high-value chemicals [10-13]. And it is widely used in organic synthesis, pesticides, and other fields [14-16]. Hydrogenation, as one of the most important high-value conversion means of FFL, has drawn great attention from researchers [17, 18]. However, due to the complexity of the hydrogenation reaction of FFL (aldehyde/furan ring hydrogenation), multiple competitive reactions may be involved, which leads to different hydrogenation products from FFL, such as furfuryl alcohol (FAL), tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFAL), 2-methylfuran, furan, etc [19-25]. Among them, FAL as an important intermediate is widely used in the preparation of phenolic resins, glass fibers, lysine, dispersants and adhesives [20, 26-28]. THFAL, as an another product of the selective hydrogenation of FFL, not only serves as a green solvent, but also has a wide range of applications in the fields of pesticides and other fields [29-31]. Therefore, the presence of a highly efficient catalyst in the reaction is particularly important in order to obtain a single hydrogenation product with high selectivity, and controlling the distribution of FFL hydrogenation products by adjusting the catalyst is also a hotspot in biomass research [32]. At present, the catalysts designed and prepared for selective hydrogenation of FFL can be roughly divided into two categories. One is the noble metal catalysts led by Pd, Pt and Ru [33-35]. Although they have achieved good catalytic effect, there is still a deficiency in the high price, cost and rarity of precious metals. The other type is non-precious metal catalysts based on Cu and Ni, although the cost is reasonable, but the harsh reaction conditions and complex preparation methods etc. have prevented them from being developed and utilized on a large scale [28, 36-38]. Therefore, it is still a challenge to rationally design and develop non-precious metal catalysts for the highly selective hydrogenation of FFL [39]. Although metal Co also has hydrogenation activity, it is commonly used as a co-catalyst, and there are relatively few in-depth studies on it [40]. As an important branch of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), ZIFs are similar to traditional aluminosilicate zeolite in structure, and they have the advantages of MOFs, namely large specific surface area, abundant and orderly pore structure, easy regulation and customizable chemical and physical properties [41-45]. They are widely used in gas adsorption/separation, chemical sensing, catalysis and other fields [46-49]. The traditional synthesis method of ZIFs adopts a solvothermal method or stirring aging method. Due to the higher energy consumption or longer reaction time, or a combination of expensive instruments and technologies to shorten the preparation time of the catalyst, it is not suitable for large-scale industrial applications. Therefore, it is urgent to design and develop a convenient and time-saving method to synthesize MOF derivative materials as an efficient catalyst for the selective hydrogenation of FFL. Inspired by methods reported in the literatures [50], in this work, we intended to develop a short-term and efficient method for synthesizing bimetallic ZnCo-ZIF with the assistance of ultrasound, and the obtained ZnCo-ZIF-US was further carbonized in an inert atmosphere to prepare the catalyst, denoted as ZnCo-US@NC-T. The advantages of ultrasound-assisted synthesis were highlighted by comparing with the effect of the catalyst prepared without ultrasound assistance. Besides, the effect of pyrolysis temperature on the catalytic performance was elaborately explored. Last but not least, under the same catalytic system, the presence of Zn in the ZnCo-ZIF-US precursor played a pivotal role with controllable selectivity toward FAL/THFAL in the hydrogenation of FFL. Experimental Synthesis of ZnCo-ZIF-US The ZnCo-ZIF-US was synthesized with the aid of ultrasound. Specifically, Zn(NO3)2 ⋅6H2O (0.2975 g, 1 mmol) and Co(NO3)2 ⋅6H2O (0.2910 g, 1 mmol) were dissolved in 15 mL methanol, which was subsequently mixed with a 15 mL methanol solution containing 2-methylimidazole (0.9852 g, 12 mmol) and kept for 20 minutes under ultrasonic condition. The sample was collected by centrifugation, washed with alcohol and vacuum drying at 60 °C for 12 h to obtain ZnCo-ZIF-US. Preparation of ZnCo-US@NC-T A certain amount of prepared ZnCo-ZIF-US was put in a porcelain boat, heated at 5 °C⋅min−1 to target temperature (500, 700 and 900 °C, respectively) in N2, and then maintained for 4 h. The resulting materials were expressed as ZnCo-US@NC-T (T refers to the calcination temperature). Preparation of comparative samples For comparison, bimetal ZnCo-ZIF was prepared using the same method, but without assistance of ultrasound, denoted as ZnCo-ZIF. Zn-ZIF-67 and Co-ZIF-67 had been synthesized as noted except for the difference in metal molar amount (without addition of Co2+/Zn2+). The obtained swatch was placed into a porcelain boat for pyrolysis at 700 °C in the same way as the synthesis of ZnCo-US@NC-T. The as-prepared products were designated as ZnCo@NC-700, Zn@NC-700 and Co@NC-700. Catalytic performance evaluation The selective hydrogenation of furfural was carried out in a 100 mL autoclave reactor which was furnished with a magnetic and temperature controller. The catalyst (∼100 mg) and FFL (0.5 mmol) were dispersed in 10 mL ethanol by ultrasonic and therewith transferred to the reactor, after purged with H2 to replace the air in the reactor 3 times, filled it with 2 MPa H2. Whereafter, the autoclave was heated to 120 °C and held for 4 h with magnetic stirring at 500 rpm. The pressure was slowly released after the reactor was cooled to room temperature with a water bath. The catalyst was recovered by centrifugal separation. The supernatant after centrifugation was filtered through a 0.22 μm syringe filter and analyzed by gas chromatography (Shimadzu GC-2014C). The concentration of FFL, FAL and THFAL was determined by the standard curve method, and the conversion of FFL and the selectivity of FAL/THFAL were determined by the following formulas. Conversion of FFL (%): C ( F F L , % ) = A − B A × 100 % The yield of FAL/THFAL (%): Y ( F A L / T H F A L , % ) = P A × 100 % The selectivity of FAL/THFAL (%): S ( F A L / T H F A L , % ) = P A − B × 100 % where A is added moles of FFL, B is remained after reaction moles of FFL, P is moles of products FAL/THFAL. Results and discussion Material characterization In this work, the effect of changes in the preparation technology of ZnCo-US@NC-T (such as preparation method and calcination temperature) on the phase composition, structure and morphology of obtained materials was studied in detail through PXRD, TEM, SEM and other characterization. PXRD test was conducted for purpose of confirmation the successful synthesis of the ZnCo-ZIF-US, comparative catalysts and their derivatives. As shown in Fig. 1 a, the PXRD patterns of both ZnCo-ZIF-US and ZnCo-ZIF were highly identical with the simulated pattern from single crystal data of ZIF-67, which proved that they have extremely similar crystal structures. Similarly, it could be seen from PXRD that Zn-ZIF-67 and Co-ZIF-67 for comparison had also been successfully synthesized (Fig. S1a). To our astonishment, the diffraction peaks of ZnCo-US@NC-500 were almost completely similar to the synthesized ZnCo-ZIF-US, indicated that the structure of ZnCo-ZIF-US precursor was still maintained at the calcination temperature of 500 °C, which could also be proved by the thermogravimetric curve (TG) that the complete collapse temperature of ZnCo-ZIF-US was around 520 °C (Fig. S2). Nevertheless, all the characteristic peaks of the ZIF framework were disappeared for the ZnCo-US@NC-700 and replaced by the three peaks located at 44.26°, 51.54° and 75.80°, which corresponded to the (111), (200) and (220) faces of metal cobalt (JCPDS no.15-0806). The broad peak at about 25.99° was matched well with the graphitic carbon (JCPDS no. 65-6212) that derived from the carbonization of organic ligands. Compared with ZnCo-US@NC-700, although the peaks of ZnCo-US@NC-900 were the same as the former, the peak width was significantly narrower and the peak diffraction was pronounced stronger, indicating that the degree of crystallinity and particle size of the Co particles may be both increased (Fig. 1b). Likewise, three peaks of Co nanoparticles at 44.26, 51.54 and 75.80° could also be observed in Co@NC-700 and ZnCo@NC-700, while Zn@NC-700 only contained the peak of disordered carbon (002) (Figs. 1b and S1b). It clearly seen from SEM images that both ZnCo-ZIF-US and ZnCo-ZIF were the typical polyhedral morphology of ZIF-67, but the difference was that the particle size produced by ultrasound-assisted synthesis (ZnCo-ZIF-US) was more uniform than ZnCo-ZIF (Fig. 2 a, b). After calcination, the surface of the ZnCo-US@NC-T had changed, masses of the polyhedral edges of ZnCo-US@NC-500 almost disappear and became more rounded than those of ZnCo-ZIF-US, that was also proved by TEM (Figs. 2c and 3 i). Interestingly, the pyrolysis provoked the occurrence of carbon nanotubes on the surface of ZnCo-US@NC-700 particles, which was the result of the surface catalysis of Co nanoparticles, and its surface significantly shrank, similar to that of ZnCo@NC-700. It was worth mentioning that, unlike most other ZIF-derived carbon nanotubes, we obtained it by one-step pyrolysis in a non-reducing atmosphere and no additional carbon source [51]. Compared with ZnCo-US@NC-700, white bright spots appeared on the surface of ZnCo-US@NC-900, which were proved to be Co nanoparticles (Fig. 3g). The surface of ZnCo-US@NC-T was transformed what with the disintegration of the carbon skeleton in the calcination process. All the obtained materials (ZnCo-ZIF-US, ZnCo-ZIF and other comparative catalysts) were further characterized by TEM and were found that they all inherited the polyhedral morphology of ZIF-67 (Figs. 3 and 5). The difference was that in ZnCo-US@NC-700, in addition to the obvious appearance of cobalt nanoparticles, the periphery of the material shrank significantly and was surrounded by carbon nanotubes (Fig. 3b). It was not negligible that the end of the nanotube was also encapsulated with cobalt nanoparticles which could be proved by EDS-Mapping (Fig. 3f). The EDS mapping image of ZnCo-US@NC-700 showed homogeneous dispersion of C, N, Zn, and Co (Fig. 3c). Similar results could be observed for ZnCo@NC-700 catalyst, except that the particle size was not uniform (Figs. 3d, e, 4 and S3). Uniformity in size may be very beneficial for exposed catalytically active sites, so ZnCo-US@NC-700 had higher catalytic performance. As shown by HRTEM (Fig. 3h), its lattice fringe was 0.205 nm, which corresponded to the (111) crystal plane of cobalt. Compared with ZnCo-US@NC-700 (∼6.96 nm) (Fig. 4 ), the sharp increase of Co nanoparticles in ZnCo-US@NC-900 (∼8.65 nm) was attributed to the influence of the calcination temperature, that was, the particles were prone to agglomeration with the high temperature (Fig. 3j), which also further explained the reason why the aforementioned XRD peak intensity of the material had become stronger (Fig. 1b). About the comparative catalysts Zn@NC-700 and Co@NC-700, the morphological analysis indicated that the surface of Zn@NC-700 particles had a partially agglomerated structure and the edges became smooth (Figs. 5 c and S4c). Although the Co@NC-700 maintained a polyhedral morphology, the edges showed obvious shrinkage and a small number of particles agglomerated, which could be observed more intuitively by TEM (Figs. 5d and S4d). Nitrogen adsorption/desorption experiments were carried out in the cause of having an in-depth understanding of the specific surface area (SA) and pore volume (PV) of the materials at different calcination temperatures. As shown in Fig. 6 , the isotherm of ZnCo-US@NC-700 showed a sharp increase at the low-pressure area adsorption, demonstrating the existence of micropores, while the obvious hysteresis loop in the high-pressure area proved the existence of mesopores, which was also proved by the pore size distribution diagram. Additionally, the SA and PV of ZnCo-US@NC-T could be respectively calculated in the light of the BET and total pore volume model calculation method, which changed enormously with the increase of pyrolysis temperature (Table S1). For ZnCo-US@NC-500, which still remained ZnCo-ZIF-US framework, the SA and PV have comparatively little change. Comparing as-obtained materials (ZnCo-US@NC-700, ZnCo-US@NC-900, Zn@NC-700, Co@NC-700 and ZnCo@NC-700), it could be found that the ZnCo-US@NC-700 had the largest SA (381.13 m2 g−1) of all the samples, and the PV had an alike tendency. Therefore, ZnCo-US@NC-700 was more adequate as the first-rank materials than others, because the presence of large SA and mesopores could expand the contact area between the reactants and provided more catalytically active sites, which would help improve the catalytic performance of the material. The electronic state of ZnCo-US@NC-700 composite was investigated by XPS. It can be seen from the survey of XPS that C, N, Zn and Co were present in the material (Fig. S6). The existence valence of Co was investigated by high resolution XPS spectra of Co 2p (Fig. 7 a), where the binding energy at 778.5 eV and 793.7 eV peaks belonged to the 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 regions of zero-valent Co, respectively [52]. The peaks at 779.5 eV/795.9 eV indicate the existence Co3+, and the peaks at 782.5 eV/797.7 eV indicate the presence of Co2+. This may be caused by oxidation of the material surface exposed to air [53-55]. In addition, it could be known from the N 1s spectrum that the material was composed of pyridine nitrogen with a binding energy of 398.8 eV, pyrrole nitrogen with 400.8 eV and graphitic nitrogen with 401.2 eV, among which the content of pyridine nitrogen was the highest in the material (Fig. 7b) [56, 57]. This results confirmed the successful synthesis of nitrogen-doped carbon materials [58]. Catalytic performance evaluation and optimization Through a series of characterization above, it could be determined that the pyrolysis process had an influence on the materials, so the effect of the pyrolysis process on the catalytic performance was discussed here. The catalytic performance of the materials prepared above in FFL hydrogenation reaction was studied. As shown in Fig. 8 , the FFL hydrogenation was carried out in ethanol at 120°C under 2 MPa H2 for 4 h with ZnCo-ZIF-US catalyst, about 5.13% FFL conversion with 9.16% selectivity of FAL was obtained. ZnCo-US@NC-500 showed 5.75% conversion of the reaction which almost no obvious changed compared with ZnCo-ZIF-US but the selectivity of FAL increased sharply to 94.71%. While, it was found that the FFL conversion could reach 100% and 91.54% selectivity of the FAL when used the ZnCo-US@NC-700 as the catalyst. ZnCo-US@NC-900 gave the 100% FFL conversion the same as ZnCo-US@NC-700, but the selectivity of FAL was only 86.85% (Fig. 8). There were two main reasons for this result, one was that Co nanoparticles had agglomerated under this high temperature treatment (Fig. 2e). The other was due to the evaporation of Zn at 900 °C, which leaded to a decrease in the Zn content in the catalyst, resulted in a decrease in the selectivity of the reaction. This result could be further proved by the ICP test (Table S2). Then, in order to prove the synergistic effect between Zn and Co, the catalytic performance of Zn@NC-700 and Co@NC-700 was evaluated, respectively. It could be found that Zn@NC-700 only gave 8.32% FAL conversion with 92.62% FAL selectivity. The conversion of FFL could reach 100% with Co@NC-700 catalyst, while the selectivity of FAL was only 0.45% (Fig. 9 a), but it was worth noting that the selectivity of THFAL could reach 90.00% at this time. Whereas Zn@NC-700 had no catalytic effect on FFL hydrogenation conversion to THFAL. ZnCo-US@NC-700 afforded 4.96% conversion of THFAL (Fig. S8). Therefore, the synergistic effect of bimetallic ZnCo was conducive to the highly selective preparation of FAL, and doped of Zn could achieve the purpose of regulating selective hydrogenation of FFL to FAL/THFAL. Finally, in order to prove the importance of ultrasound assistance, with the utilization of ZnCo@NC-700 catalyst, substantial decrease in FFL conversion (87.83%) and FAL selectivity (61.93%) was observed (Fig. 9a). The results showed that ultrasound assistance was indispensable in the process of synthesizing MOF precursors. Based on this result and combined with literature research, we speculated the reason that the acoustic cavitation effect will be generated in the ultrasonic process, which can cause local high temperature and high pressure, resulting in extremely fast heating and cooling rate, which may change the motion rate of molecules and thus increase the binding ability between substances [59]. Recycle Experiment The recycling of the catalyst will reduce the cost in line with the concept of energy saving and emission reduction. Therefore, we selected ZnCo-US@NC-700 as a catalyst to conduct a recycling experiment to evaluate its performance. After the reaction, the catalyst was washed for three times with absolute ethanol and dried before being used in the next catalytic cycle. The recyclability of the catalyst still maintained 100% FFL conversion and the FAL selectivity remained above 90% after four cycles of recycling (Fig. 9b). We also conducted a reusability experiment of Co@NC-700, as shown in Fig. S9, the conversion of FFL was 100% and the selectivity of THFAL was nearly unchanged after four cycles. In order to confirm whether the structure of recycled ZnCo-US@NC-700 catalyst was similar to the fresh one, to begin with, the PXRD test was performed on it. As shown in Fig. 9c, the PXRD pattern of ZnCo-US@NC-700 was exhibiting almost identical diffraction peaks before and after the reaction, indicating that the structure of the ZnCo-US@NC-700 catalyst hardly changed after the cycle. Consistent with the results of SEM and TEM characterization (Figs. 9d, e), compared with the newly prepared catalyst, the microstructure of the recovered catalyst was still well maintained and there was no significant agglomeration of Co nanoparticles. CONCLUSION In summary, a simple, fast and energy-saving method was proposed for the synthesis of bimetallic ZIF materials and a simple one-step pyrolysis method to obtain MOF-derived nanomaterials. The experimental results in the FFL hydrogenation reaction showed that even if using cheap transition metals as catalysts, the synergy between Zn and Co in ZnCo-US@NC-700 still provided excellent catalytic performance in the selective reduction of FFL to FAL. This material had a high degree of controllability in the FFL hydrogenation reaction and could be doped with Zn to achieve the purpose of regulating the product distribution. FAL could be obtained with high selectivity through the synergistic effect of Zn and Co bimetal. THFAL with a furfural conversion of 100% and a selectivity of 90% was obtained when only cobalt was present in the material. In addition, the catalyst still maintained excellent catalytic activity after being recycled. This study may provide an idea for the design and preparation of non-noble metal doping catalysts that selectively regulate the distribution of furfural hydrogenation products. coredata.dc:description: Furfural, as one of the most important and attractive platform molecules, could produce high-value chemicals through selective hydrogenation, which had attracted wide attention in recent years. Hereon, a ZnCo bimetal ZIF (ZnCo-ZIF-US) was quickly and efficiently prepared by an ultrasonic-assisted method, and a series of nitrogen-doped carbon-coated bimetallic composites (ZnCo-US@NC-T, T refers to the calcination temperature) were prepared by a one-step calcination technique from ZnCo-ZIF-US and their structures were characterized in detail by PXRD, SEM, TEM, and XPS etc. The obtained ZnCo-US@NC-700 showed higher catalytic performance in the selective hydrogenation of furfural to furfuryl alcohol than the derivatives of ZnCo bimetal ZIF prepared without ultrasonic-assisted. Surprisingly, the results showed the presence or absence of Zn in the catalysts could regulate the hydrogenation products of furfural to produce furfuryl alcohol or tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol. In addition, the catalyst could be recycled with almost no significant change in catalytic performance and its microstructure was still well maintained. This work provides an ingenious strategy for the selective regulation of biomass products.
coredata.dc:title: MOF derived non-noble metal catalysts to control the distribution of furfural selective hydrogenation products
